text: I'm trying to put myself in the place
for a moment as how you've enter you
come down a ramp and into a security
facility and I made that all wood
because it would be more user-friendly
to them that instead of being a a harsh
edge to go through like we have in the
u.s. security is pretty ugly
so he comes through this wooden building
and you go up then up a ramp back up a
ramp into the entry under one of those
beautiful cones as you cross this
threshold the temperature drops like at
least 15 degrees I became aware that
they liked being outdoors instead of an
air-conditioned spaces and so I was
trying to figure out some way to cool
the outdoor spaces and I thought of a
teepee and the teepee takes the hot air
out and so I took some paper and I made
a bunch of teepees and put them around
the what I considered the public spaces
on the model as a just as a placeholder
- that something had to be solved and
the client group came here and they
looked at all the models and they picked
that one they said that's incredible you
really understand our culture that and I
couldn't figure out what they're talking
about I realized that the a repetitive
simple shape like a dome is something
that they are used to in their history
and to build a structure like that isn't
the cheapest thing to do I mean you
could probably air-conditioned the
outdoor space for less than it cost to
build out but it became an important
aesthetic element that they loved
I've been to a lot of mosques and I've
seen a lot of the Turkish sin on and the
Hagia Sophia and I've been there a lot
of times in last year's what is this
directly significant what you think
about is the domes when you go to the
Blue Mosque you think about the domes
but if you're on axis it's all
symmetrical but you don't stand on axes
you walk around the building and as you
walk around it becomes messy because
it's not symmetrical the walkways on
each floor would be a glass floor and
glass rails so it'd be very ephemeral so
the Geiser and white women aren't black
and I had this fantasy of the white and
black in this reflective environment
becoming an art piece in a living art
piece
and I've talked to the Emiratis about it
and reason I'm so happy about that
they're building it as I think in the
end they're their intentions are to show
these cultures can be together in one
room and talk to each other I think it's
some kind of a revolution and I think
it's given them political mess of all
these countries including ours um
there's a clarity and talking to each
other through art through classical
music through literature rather than
trying to politicize and one-upsmanship
and all the military options that and
they're threatening everybody it seems
that the art takes the threat out it
becomes more humanistic more
it's more questioning it's more who it's
like who are we why are we why do we why
do we talk alike why do we know why can
we relate to their art and they can
relate to art and why don't we do more
of it that's the exciting thing and
hopefully that when this building is
built it will deliver that message and
if it does it'll be the architecture
will be part of something bigger
